description: Recorded since 1904, altering the earlier gaberdine (“long, coarse outer garment”) (since 1520), from Spanish gabardina (perhaps influenced by gabán (“overcoat”) and tabardina (“coarse coat”)), from Middle French galverdine, itself probably from (Old or Middle) High German wallevart (“pilgrimage”), in the sense of “pilgrim's cloak” (from wallen (“to ambulate”) + vart (“journey”)).

entries.meaning: (uncountable, countable) A type of woolen cloth with a diagonal ribbed texture on one side.
examples: The merchant found gabardines with finer ribs sold better here.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, countable) A similar fabric, made from cotton.
(countable, historical) A yellow robe that Jews in England were compelled to wear in the year 1189 as a mark of distinction.
